instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1708: What is A1708? A1708 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2017, 2016 with EMC 3164, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00840, 820-00875..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage - Turns on slowly and won't boot SSD or USB.
threads.message:
First time working on a USB-C board...

Liquid hit <CHIP>U8210</CHIP> and <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>.  No visible corrosion, just sticky mess.  The rest of the board looks flawless.

Cleaned up <CHIP>U8210</CHIP> and verified <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> are being output.

Flowed flux at low temp and ultrasonic cleaned to attempt to remove anything under <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>.

Upon inserting USB-C (either port) it takes 20.4v and 0.65A and fans start but screen remains off.

The amps slowly climb from 0.65A to 2.95A and after about 45 - 50 seconds the screen will come on.

With customer's SSD installed I get flashing ? folder once machine turns on.  SSD is warm (borderline hot).  Zero liquid damage in the area of SSD though.  Unfortunately I don't have another <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> on hand or another one of these SSDs...

I attempted to boot from a known good test drive over USB.  It will give Apple logo, no loading bar, and gets stuck forever.

I also attempted to boot from two newly created USB installers.  They also give Apple logo, progress bar starts, then machine reboots...

Lastly I tried diagnostic/internet recovery.  It shows that there are no available wifi network.  

It is possible corrosion under <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> would cause all of this?  I have a new on on the way just in case.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage - Turns on slowly and won't boot SSD or USB.
threads.message:
<CHIP>U3200</CHIP> should be good if you get now 20V on both USB-C ports.

Try USB macOS disconnecting internal SSD first.

threads.message:

<CHIP>U3200</CHIP> should be good if you get now 20V on both USB-C ports.

[/QUOTE]
I should have mentioned that SSD was out when attempting USB boot.

threads.message:
Do NOT quote entire post, visible few centimeters above.
Please, maintain forum aesthetic.

Try to boot Linux Live, or Windows through USB.
You may need to clean ME in BIOS...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage - Turns on slowly and won't boot SSD or USB.
threads.message:
Windows tried to boot and locked up.

Ubuntu tried to boot too, stopped in the middle, then shut down.

Is this BIOS appropriate to try? [URL]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-no-wi-fi-no-drive-detected.57480/#post-59471[/URL]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage - Turns on slowly and won't boot SSD or USB.
threads.message:
same result with that BIOS too.  

When I tried to PRAM reset I held the buttons for the 50 seconds and the screen lit up but nothing on the display.  It remained lit for about 10 seconds and then the machine turned off and didn't auto-power on again. Does PRAM reset work differently on this model?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage - Turns on slowly and won't boot SSD or USB.
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage - Turns on slowly and won't boot SSD or USB.
threads.message:
Something strange, if PRAM reset doesn't work properly.
Do you have Medusa programmer?
It can also reset NVRAM...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage - Turns on slowly and won't boot SSD or USB.
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage - Turns on slowly and won't boot SSD or USB.
threads.message:
Do you get correct voltage at <CHIP>U8210</CHIP> outputs?

The BIOS in the link should have PRAM reset done with Medusa.
I don't have another BIOS for 00840.
Upload original BIOS of your board and I will try to clean it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage - Turns on slowly and won't boot SSD or USB.
threads.message:
I still have this thing laying around if you are willing to try to clean BIOS.

[URL unfurl="true"]https://drive.google.com/file/d/1MKNnlvZOlQ5pyhP2dimIloq0Yj4whp6g/view?usp=sharing[/URL]

Yes, <CHIP>U8210</CHIP> is giving the correct outputs.
